comments.commentBody: Learn by others mistakes. Let's not stick our heads in the sand and retreat away from a very viable and safe energy source. We need nuclear energy to break our dependance on fossil fuels. I hope that common sense prevails.

Not that I favor the implications, but I would note that futbol will never take off in the U.S.A. as long as blatant errors by referees continue to exist in the game. People were worked up about Edu's goal that was called back against Slovenia, but Lampard's non-goal would be an absolute scandal. For better or worse, Americans want perfection in their refs. As a result, we get reviews (and interminable, yet often inconclusive, reviews at that) in every sport - baseball, football, basketball, etc. Even if the ultimate placement of the ball is basically arbitrary in American football, there's a sense in which Americans aspire to a game in which referee discretion and, more importantly, referee mistakes, cannot influence the outcome of the game. I'm not making a normative statement one way or the other, as I actually prefer the vagaries that arise in the run of play (although Edu's non-goal was a travesty, as was Lampard's, as was Tevez's goal against Mexico), but the typical American fan will not put up with a shrug of the shoulders from FIFA officials when it comes to clearly unjust outcomes.

If the nuclear industry wants to build more nuclear plants, let it do so without government loan guarantees and taxpayer-paid disaster insurance. Meanwhile, I suggest that taxpayers would get better value by providing loan guarantees and subsidies to real green technologies like solar, wind, geothermal, biomass, energy conservation, etc. The nuclear industry got its chance. Now let renewables have theirs. And, by the way, enough of comparing "clean" nuclear to climate warming fossil fuels as though those were the only two choices. Nuclear is dirty, too. We need to innovate beyond them all asap. I say we can if innovators are not blocked at every turn by entrenched corporate power and politicians beholden to the nuclear and fossil fuel industries.
Oh, and, of course, I MEANT to add this:  Happy Birthday to Daughter of Deb!
Hands up from those who, like me, had "seatbelt" before  the "swat team" finally came to the rescue. Great puzzle.  Thanks, Mike and Will.

I can't believe I actually finished... I was so OUTWITted by this puzzle - there were so many misdirections - I thought Handsome Dan was the name of the Yale bulldog. I tried to figure out some kind of a textbook for 5D; a slicer or diet for 19A. I was lost for a long TYME, but I couldn't TEAR AWAY til it was done. Whew! TWIlight was so clever, but now - G'nite!
11:51

I remember  reading that   George  Soros invested big in   Brazil's  Petrogas oil industry   a year ago.   Can't help but wonder whether  his latest economic  conference machinations  and   the President's recent trip to Brazil ( at a time when we were "dithering" about what to do  about  urgent  problems in  Libya)   are somehow connected.  The current president seems bound and determined to spend us into oblivion and Soros   seems bound and determined to destroy capitalism ! (  Can't believe that  an American president has involved this country in a civil war,   with others now in charge of the military action,  at a time that we have  the largest deficit  in our history. )  Are any adults awake in Washington?

This is a near-perfect if not pitch-perfect template of American leadership in international conflict resolution process. Just in 5 days, with its 'unique capabilities', having led the allied forces in the air strikes, USA was able to establish a semblance of no-fly zone in Libya. Now, NATO is taking over the leadership of enforcing the No-Fly status in the theatre in next couple of days, and considering to take over the broader responsibility by establishing UN mandate what it called 'No-Fly Plus' to protecting the civilians from Qaddafi's wrath in whatever way coalition would deem necessary.
A brilliant diplomacy by Hilary with the NATO members finally produced this outcome so swiftly.
Thus far, the rules of engagement seemed also like a Best Practice Process.
?By design, Obama administration desperately needed to avoid USA 'face' in it which now seems an achievable goal. Earlier, the regional body, Arab League had stamped it,Europe/NATO cleared it and finally UNO security council had accorded an appropriate mandate unanimously like never before.
Of much greater significance, the UNO is now again looking relevant!

Both the UN and NATO are useless organizations. Libya is perfect for them. #209 - You are right. Dubya would not have wasted our resources on such a meaningless part of the world for a people who cheered the Locherbie bomber home. He never would have asked NATO because we wouldn't be there in the first place.
It's bad enough that we are involved in Iraq and Afghanistan but at least they have some strategic significance. Libya has nothing we want. Does anyone really care what happens in Africa? I haven't found any evidence that would lead me to believe so over the past decades. Why start now?
What we should have done is supply the rebels with a huge number of weapons and let them fight it out on their own. It would make for great TV on Al Jazeera.

The truth is, the Obama administration went into the operation here with less of a coalition than George W. Bush had for the invasion of Iraq. In Iraq, at least, our belief was that we had the threat that the other Hussein had WMD.
Now what Barry?

Hillary Clinton was as vague about what is happening as President Obama is. He needs to sit down at a news conference with credible journalists and explain in detail what America's goals are in Lybia and directly answer the "what if" questions,that the American people want to know.... That's what transparency is all about.
OK, now for a "no-fly zone" over the "settlement areas" in neo-Israel where the Palestinians have as real a complaint as anyone else in the area!

Really, NATO is actually going to accomplish something. Surprise, surprise, surprise. Glad to see them take a leading role for a change. NATO in Afric, interesting. Maybe a new name is needed for the 21st century.

A big mess. Many innocent lives will be lost on both sides as the outlines of a civil war emerges. The rebels will get stronger armed by coalition forces. Khadaffi will fight unto death for his is an ideological commitment. IN the meantime, innocents will suffer on both sides, a weak economy will be ruined, valuable and scarce resources that should be used to bolster recovery in Europe and America will be wasted.

Annonymous source liars and fabrications will pass for news. Lies will fly like flies. Discerning the truth will become impossible.

All in all a very big mess. The sooner bombings stop, the better.

With demonstrations and the dynamic actions of those who wish a more democratic Middle East.It's time that the United States formulate a new middle eastern policy , one that is not based on oil but human rights. Arab countries have been around for a long time longer than the usefulness of of oil from the ground. This is the first time that we in the West have had to deal withit. Our politicians must get it  The earthquake is just beginning.The American public needs straight talk not just talk.

This is NATO's third "humanitarian" war in twenty years. Count Bosnia in '95 and Kosovo in '99 as 1 and 2.

In Bosnia, Serbs (in both Bosnia and Serbia) were given an ultimatium not to attack the "safe areas." They did and an air bombing campaign successfully forced them to Dayton in 20 days.

In Kosovo, Serbia was given an ultimatium to stop the ethnic cleansing and murder, leave, and allow a peacekeeping force in. They didn't and an air bombing capaign successfully forced them out in 77 days.

Now, an ultimatium has been given to stop military action with the threat to go house-to-house and murder opponents. An air campaign is now underway with a no-fly zone achieved and initial but limited success against ground forces.

Events of our doing and not in our control had evolved to a point where the house-to-house threats were on the verge of becoming reality.

Calls were made for a no fly zone and attacks on the ground forces were made by many leading Republicans in Congress and several Presidental wanabe's. Now that events have forced a decision to act or to stand aside - and the right decision to act has been taken - many of these same Republicans are howling foul - revealing in clear terms their own hypocrisy and ambitions.

In the same vein many Democrats are calling for inaction and appeasement carefully washing their hands of any responsibility for a blood bath - a similar hyprocrisy and similar ambition for their own voting bloc.

So like all unfolding events this is fraught with danger and uncertainty - there is no perfect plan or decision. There is the clear minimum goal that innocent people will not be slaughtered by Qadaffi. A somewhat hopeful goal is Qadaffi goes. An unlikely but ideal goal is that the first step is taken to someday leading a semblence of democracy in Libya - Bosnia and Kosovo have made slow positive steps in that dreiction - but these steps take time, determination, very careful and measured thinking, not missing opportunities, and not failing to compromise when necessary.
So, NATO can bomb them but they cannot bomb themselves!  Maybe everyone should mind their own business!

On to Iran! On to North Korea!
Lets jackboot our way around the globe.

Not because we want to -- it's because we have to. Decency demands it ... unless, of course, there's a Republican in the White House.

“We didn’t want to get sucked into an operation with uncertainty at the end,” the senior administration official said. “In some ways, how it turns out is not on our shoulders.”

I give up: Why not?

Plans to invade Libya are more than 10 years old.  Search Wesley Clark. This has 0 to do with humanitarian efforts.  Exactly who are the rebels.  Look into that, people.  Find out who is funding them.

Re: MW "Increasing capital gains and income tax will result in even more of the tax burden on the middle classes. can someone who advocates this position please explain their reasoning?"

Yes. The corporate income tax is a tax that harms profitable mid-size or small companies. Obviously the truly powerful businesses already do not pay it. A company is a group of people serving a market need and performing work. This is not something we want to discourage. GE is not evil. America is far stronger for having a wonderful company like GE here. The alternative is we all live in caves and eat dirt. It is anti-intellectual to suggest life without large corporations is really good. We know nothing of that. Large corporations are highly efficient human work and human service units. They provide us some of our most cherished achievements and possessions.

My salient point is, if you want to tax the powerful PEOPLE in this land, you can do so. Bump the capital gains taxes higher -- such as those over 1 million dollars. I suggest a 40% rate (let's not get too out of hand). With the massive boost in revenue under control, we should cut the corporate tax on small businesses. It is possible to collect taxes without this cartoonish focus on corporations. No person can use corporate wealth unless he or she pays income tax on it. So, we need not tax the corporate wealth. It is a knee jerk reaction that sounds good, but is actually totally counter-productive. GE actually becomes stronger because it can invest whereas a smaller firm must pay the tax, so they cannot achieve the same performance, and cannot win bids against GE. This tax is conceived out of emotion and not a coherent morality.

Many years ago it occurred to me, in the much broader context of the changing business ethics and strategies that what had been GE's motto in the mid 20th Century - "Progress is our most important product", had become transformed into "Profit is our most important progress".  To see GE doing what it has to in order to maintain profitability and shareholder value by today's standards should surprise no one.

lol, all this hand wringing about the GOP enabling the evil corporations. Did't Mr Change just appoint Immelt to head his business outreach group. Why is it so hard for the left, with all its education and sophistication, to figure out that the Democratic party is a sham front for the monied elite too.

If corporations are individuals, they can pay taxes on their revenues, thank you.  All revenues.  They can take the standard deduction, deduct mortgage interest on a single headquarters, etc.  But tax the revenue, not the profit.  I get taxed on revenue, let them get taxed on revenue too.

To all the tea partiers and conservatives who see no problem with this or the direction the country has been heading in the last 40 years: What would jesus do? Based on the current Republican philosophy, they would have to answer that Jesus would bomb Iraq, end programs that help poor people (most of whom want to work and are looking for jobs), and deregulate health care in order to deny medical insurance for children with pre-identified conditions. If not, then really: what would jesus do?
